resource.chars:
21. 
He proceeds to mean the observations in such 
a manner as to smooth out fluctuations, a process which 
is in itself open to objection under the particular 
circumstances of the case. 
As a result he gets varying difference of 
pressure, nowhere amounting to more than an equivalent 
of 250 feet in height, a result almost precisely similar 
to that which would have been obtained i<s>n<\s>f Lieutenant 
Royds had marched along the sea face of the Barrier. 
Such a result can only afford negative proofs, 
but the reader of Mr Curtis' paper is not so informed. 
After being told that a rise in level may 
safely be assumed (I emphatically protest against the 
use of my own words in support of this) it is suggested 
to him that he may even assume a rise of 2 feet per mile 
along the line traversed "as according better<s>"<\s> with the 
facts" and as giving a "barometric gradient sufficient 
to account fully . . . . . for the wind distribution 
observed at the "Discovery's Winter Quarters." 
In this manner Mr Royds' pressure observations 
are made to support his reversed winds and the Anti-
cyclonic theory. 
After this it is not surprising to find such 
expressions as 'the dominant winds blew from the 
Eastwards' used without the shade of <s>the<\s> a doubt; the 
theory advances unfettered. 
<u>I submit<\s>
